messageBody:
Rakesh wrote:

> So it will execute all the TestCases, and the setUp() and tearDown()
> function makes sure that the fixture
> is not executing every time a TestCase is called.
> So I have initialization of my application only once, and all the
> TestCases run in the same environment.

OK. This is totally different from "repeating test cases".

It appears to me that you want to execute some setup code once, execute
an entire TestSuite, then execute some teardown code once. Is that correct?

If it is, then look at TestSetup and the JUnit FAQ. Google keyworks:
JUnit FAQ TestSetup.

> Now I want to be able to run the same TestSuite again and again, till I
> myself don't stop the application.
> I looked into the RepeatedTestCase class, but couldn't get it working
> for me in my required manner.
> Can you give me some pointers on how to use RepeatedTestCase class
> As I am not quite clear on that, and couldn't find documentation on
> this.

My above comment is not quite right, then.

You want to do this:
1. Start JVM.
2. Execute one-time setup code.
3. Execute your TestSuite many times.
4. Tear down the JVM.

The solution you need depends on how you run your tests.

If you want to use the text-based test runner, you're out of luck. Each
invocation of the text-based test runner runs in its own JVM, so if you
want to do one-time setup of data in the JVM and execute a suite n
times, that won't happen. If your one-time setup is for something
outside the JVM, then you essentially have to remember to do the setup
and teardown as needed.

If you can use the Swing-based test runner, there is hope. Override the
method terminate() to invoke your one-time tear down code before the
test runner terminates. Wrap starting the test runner in your own main()
method that performs your one-time setup first. Here is the code.

public class EnvironmentSetupRunner {
public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
oneTimeEnvironmentSetUp();

new TestRunner() {
public void terminate() {
oneTimeEnvironmentTearDown();
super.terminate();
}
}
.start(
new String[] { AnotherSetGlobalDataTest.class.getName()});

}

private static void oneTimeEnvironmentTearDown() {
System.out.println("Teardown");
}

private static void oneTimeEnvironmentSetUp() {
System.out.println("Setup");
}
}

Neat little trick, and it's going in my book. :)
